name: New York City
intro_vibe: The Concrete Jungle: Fast, loud, kind but not nice, and the only place where 4am pizza is a food group.

general_info.description: New York is a collection of five distinct boroughs, each with its own rhythm. It rewards efficiency and punishes hesitation. It is gritty, glamorous, and relentless. The locals are 'kind' (they will help you carry a stroller up the stairs) but not 'nice' (they won't smile while doing it). It is a city of layers, where 19th-century history sits directly underneath 21st-century ambition.

weather_breakdown.name: January
weather_breakdown.clothing: Heavy coat, thermal layers, waterproof boots

weather_breakdown.name: June
weather_breakdown.clothing: Summer clothes, light jacket for A/C

etiquette_tips: The Sidewalk Code: Treat the sidewalk like a highway. Walk Right, Pass Left. Never stop in the middle; pull over to the side. Groups must single up to let others pass.
The Backpack Rule: On the subway, take your backpack OFF and hold it between your legs. Wearing it doubles your footprint and hits people. It is the #1 tourist marker.
Efficiency is Respect: Moving fast is how New Yorkers show respect for other people's time. Don't stop in the middle of the sidewalk. Step to the side.
Kind, Not Nice: A New Yorker won't smile at you or do small talk, but if you fall down the stairs, they will be the first to pick you up. Don't confuse speed with rudeness.

Tipping Nuance: 20% pre-tax is the minimum for sit-down service. Bad service? Still 15-18%. For counter service/tablets, $1-2 or skipping is fine. Bars are $1/beer or $2/cocktail. Housekeeping is $3-5/day. It is not optional; it is their wage.
The Subway Swagger: Let people OFF before you get ON. Stand aside. If a car is empty in rush hour, DO NOT GET IN (it has a broken A/C or a bad smell).
No Greetings: Do not say hello to strangers in elevators or hallways. Silence is privacy. Directness is valued; if you need help, ask directly and you will receive it.
Pizza Rules: Fold the slice down the center ('Libretto style'). Never use a fork and knife unless you want to be ridiculed. Order 'Regular' or 'Plain' slice, not 'Cheese'.
Escalator Discipline: Stand Right, Walk Left. Blocking the left side is a major offense.

Eye Contact: We ignore each other to give privacy in a crowded city. If you see someone yelling or talking to themselves ('Showtime' performers included), do not engage, do not stare, just keep walking.

neighborhoods.name: Chinatown
neighborhoods.description: A dense, cash-heavy enclave that feels like a city within a city. It is not a tourist trap, but a living community of fishmongers, herbalists, and bakeries. It offers the cheapest and most authentic food in Manhattan.

neighborhoods.name: West Village
neighborhoods.description: Once the center of 1960s bohemia and the gay rights movement (Stonewall), it is now a playground for celebrities. Its winding, off-grid streets (some still cobblestone) defy the Manhattan grid system. Navigation here is landmark-based.

neighborhoods.name: Williamsburg
neighborhoods.description: Formerly a gritty industrial hub dominated by the Domino Sugar Refinery, it has transformed into a global capital of trends. Expect converted warehouse lofts, waterfront parks, and incredible skyline views.

neighborhoods.name: Astoria & LIC
neighborhoods.description: The heart of Queens, historically anchored by a massive Greek population and Kaufman Studios. It offers authentic beer gardens and skyline views without the Manhattan price tag.

neighborhoods.name: Harlem
neighborhoods.description: The birthplace of the Harlem Renaissance in the 1920s. It remains a cultural capital with historic brownstones, the legendary Apollo Theater, and a vibrant community energy.

neighborhoods.name: Ridgewood
neighborhoods.description: Identified as a top neighborhood to watch in 2025. It offers a mix of historic architecture and new cultural venues, serving as a quieter, slightly more affordable alternative to the now-commercialized Williamsburg.

neighborhoods.name: Bushwick
neighborhoods.description: The hub for underground nightlife, warehouse raves, and street art. It is less polished than Manhattan, offering a grittier, industrial aesthetic.

neighborhoods.name: Arthur Avenue (The Bronx)
neighborhoods.description: Known as the 'Real Little Italy,' this neighborhood retains the authentic markets, pork stores, and multi-generational Italian families that have largely vanished from Manhattan's Mulberry Street.

neighborhoods.name: Jackson Heights
neighborhoods.description: The most diverse zip code on earth. 'Little India/Himalaya' meets a massive Latin American hub. The place for Tibetan momos and Colombian arepas.

neighborhoods.name: Flushing
neighborhoods.description: A massive, modern Asian metropolis. Offers a wider diversity of regional cuisines (Sichuan, Northern, Taiwanese) than Manhattan's Chinatown.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The Subway is the lifeline. Taxis are for rain.
details: OMNY vs. MetroCard: The MetroCard is sunsetting. Use OMNY (tap credit card/phone) at the turnstile. The 'Fare Cap' gives you free rides after 12 paid trips/week (Mon-Sun) on the SAME device.
Express vs. Local: Crucial! 'Express' trains (white circle on map) skip minor stations. 'Local' trains (black circle) stop everywhere. Locals 'cross-platform transfer' to save time.
Rush Hour: 07:30–10:00 and 16:30–18:30 are intense. Trains are packed. Pushing is physics, not aggression.
Navigation Apps: Use 'Citymapper' for subway details (which car to board). Use Google Maps for general walking.
Weekend Changes: Trains often re-route on weekends for maintenance. Check the MTA website or apps before travel.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
logistics.summary: How to survive the concrete jungle.
details: Sensory Reality: Sirens are constant. Trash bags sit on sidewalks (no alleys). In summer, the subway platforms can be 10-15°C hotter than the street. Accept the grit.
The Bathroom Code: Public restrooms are rare. Use the 'Got2Go' or 'NYRestroom' apps. Reliable options: Bryant Park, Grand Central, Macy's.
Navigation Math: 20 street blocks (North-South) = 1 mile (20 mins). Avenue blocks (East-West) are 3x longer. Use the 'Avenue Math' algorithm to find cross streets.
Money: Cards are accepted almost everywhere. Keep cash for tips, small bodegas, and street carts. ATM fees in bodegas are high.

logistics.title: The Sidewalk Code
logistics.summary: Walk right, pass left, never stop.
details: The Golden Rule: Treat the sidewalk like a highway. Walk on the right. Pass on the left.
Never Stop Here: Subway exits, top of escalators, or crosswalk corners. Stopping here creates a pile-up.
Pull Over: If you need to check a map or text, step flush against a building. Standing still in the flow of traffic is the ultimate sin.
Jaywalking (2025): Legalized, but cars still have right of way. Cross when safe, but stay alert.

logistics.title: Safety & Scams
details: Block-by-Block: Safety changes instantly. A busy street is safe; a deserted one is not. Late night, stick to populated avenues.
The Unstable: If someone is yelling or talking to themselves, ignore them. Do not stare, do not engage, just keep walking.
Times Square Scams: Costumed characters (Elmo/Mickey) will demand money ($20+) if you take a photo. 'Free' CD guys will intimidate you into paying. Ignore them.
Pedicabs: A notorious trap. They charge exorbitant per-minute rates. Avoid or negotiate price upfront.
Phone Snatching: Don't stand near the subway doors holding your phone loosely. Thieves grab them just as doors close.

must_eat.description: The 'Slice' is a distinct food group from the 'Whole Pie'. It is the fast food of daily life, eaten standing up or walking. It is thin, greasy, and foldable. Order a 'Regular' slice (not 'cheese'). Fold it to eat.

Brought by Polish-Jewish immigrants, a true NYC bagel is boiled before baking. 'Everything' seasoning is the default. The Toasting Schism: Purists say never toast a fresh morning bagel. Locals often do anyway. Know your order before reaching the counter.
The bodega breakfast staple. Served on a roll (not toast), it is efficient, salty, and cheap. Order it as one word: 'Baconeggandcheese'. Add 'saltpepperketchup' for the full experience.

This is a destination meal, not a snack. Cooked in 100-year-old anthracite coal ovens at 900°F, these pies are charred, crispy, and smoky. You must sit down, wait in line, and order the whole pie. It is a social event.

Distinct from a 'Deli' (which does cured meats), an 'Appetizing Store' specializes in smoked fish and dairy. This is where you get Lox, Sable, Whitefish Salad, and Scallion Cream Cheese. The ordering process is fast, loud, and by the numbers.

A Harlem/Bronx icon now citywide. Ground beef chopped on a grill with onions, peppers, and melted American cheese on a hero roll. A working-class staple. Authenticity check: cheese must be melted INTO the meat.

The cultural safety net of the city. Usually Greek-owned, often 24/7, with massive laminated menus. It is not gourmet; it is comfort. Highlights include endless coffee refills, disco fries, and breakfast at 3pm.

New York style cheesecake is dense, rich, and baked. It relies on heavy cream and cream cheese, not fluffiness. It is often eaten plain, without fruit toppings. A slice is substantial enough to be a meal.
The smell of winter in NYC. Carts roast honey-peanuts, cashews, and almonds on site. They also sell soft, salty pretzels with mustard. Cheap, fast, and eaten while walking to the subway.

NYC has incredible Chinese food, rooted in the massive waves of immigration to Chinatown (Manhattan) and later Flushing (Queens). Go for 'Soup Dumplings' (Xiao Long Bao) or massive banquet-style Dim Sum halls.

A Jewish deli icon. Beef brisket is brined, seasoned, smoked, and steamed to tender perfection, then hand-carved into a massive tower on rye bread. Katz's Deli (since 1888) is the historic standard-bearer.

The modern street food king. Originally for Muslim taxi drivers needing a quick halal meal, it is now ubiquitous. Chopped spiced chicken, yellow rice, and the famous 'White Sauce' (mayo-based) and 'Red Sauce' (lethal chili).

items.description: Designed in 1857 by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux as the nation's first major public park. It was conceived as a 'democratic space' for all classes to mingle, requiring the movement of millions of cartloads of earth to create. It is entirely man-made. Don't just stay at the entrance; go deep to the Ramble to find true silence or the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir for the classic jogging loop. Use lampposts to navigate.

A 1.45-mile elevated linear park built on a historic freight rail line. It weaves through buildings 30 feet above the street, connecting the Meatpacking District to Hudson Yards. It is a masterpiece of landscape architecture.

Brooklyn's masterpiece. The designers considered this their 'better' park because they weren't constrained by a rectangular grid. It features the Long Meadow, a mile of unbroken green space. Less manicured than Central Park.

Historically a potter's field (mass grave), it became the heart of the Beatnik and Folk movements. Today it is the best people-watching spot in the world, filled with musicians, chess players, and NYU students.

A vital transit hub and home to the city's most famous Greenmarket (Farmers Market). It is a center for political protests, street chess, and raw urban energy. It grounds you in the reality of daily NY life.
The ultimate food event (Saturdays). Features price-capped ($5-$6) global cuisines from the most diverse borough. A true community vibe.

The smartest free ride in New York. Running 24/7 between Manhattan and Staten Island, it provides the best views of the Statue of Liberty and the harbor without costing a cent. Join the commuters for a beer on the boat.

The best view of the Manhattan skyline. The bridge itself (completed 1883) was the world's first steel-wire suspension bridge and dubbed the 'Eighth Wonder of the World' at opening. Its construction cost its designer John Roebling his life.
A 1930s Art Deco masterpiece. It offers a better view than the Empire State Building because you can actually *see* the Empire State Building from here, alongside a sweeping view of Central Park.
The modern view experience. Immersive art, glass floors, and mirrored rooms. Very Instagram-centric but offers incredible perspectives of Midtown.
Founded in 1870, this Beaux-Arts colossus houses 5,000 years of art. It is massive. Pick one section (e.g., the Temple of Dendur, saved from the Nile) and enjoy it. Don't try to see it all.

A tour through preserved apartments at 97 Orchard Street, home to 7,000 working-class immigrants between 1863 and 1935. It offers a deeply moving look at the 'Old Law' housing reality and the waves of German, Irish, and Jewish history.
